headline: World's Best Scones! From Scotland to the Savoy to the U.S.
description: This is the best scone recipe! The addition of sour cream gives these a tender crumb. Serve them with clotted cream, butter, and a selection of jams.

video.description: As the recipe title claims, these just might be the World’s Best Scones!
video.name: World's Best Scones! From Scotland to the Savoy to the U.S.

name: World's Best Scones! From Scotland to the Savoy to the U.S.

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 400 degrees F (200 degrees C). Grease a baking sheet.
Make the scones: Sift flour, baking powder, sugar, and salt into a large bowl. Cut in butter with a pastry blender or by rubbing between fingers until lumps are the size of peas. Stir in currants.
Whisk milk and sour cream together in a measuring cup; gently stir into flour mixture until dough is moistened, being careful not to overwork the dough.
With floured hands, pat dough into 2- to 3-inch diameter balls. Place onto the prepared baking sheet and flatten lightly. Scones should slightly touch each other.
Make the egg wash: Whisk egg and milk together. Brush the tops of scones with egg wash and let them rest for about 10 minutes.
Bake in the preheated oven until the tops are golden brown, 10 to 15 minutes.

review.reviewBody: Far from world's best. The taste of baking soda was overwhelming. Had to toss them.

This is an incredibly tasty, easy treat. I often skip the raisins and swap out the egg wash with melted butter and a Turbinado sugar sprinkle. This creates a beautiful, not too sweet scone loved by everyone who has tasted them.
I’ve made these several times and they have been perfect every time.
I followed the pastry chef's idea and only added 3 tsp baking powder. I also added orange zest and chopped craisins - yum!

The best recipe ever. I grate 1/2 Cup of frozen , unsalted butter with a course cheese grater just before mixing the scone dough up. I keep the flour and other dry ingredients (nuts/fruit) in a sealed, metal mixing bowl in the fridge overnight. I take my freshly grated frozen butter and stir it into the dry mix distributing it well. Then I just whisk the egg and sour cream together and combine. I usually make 6, not 8. I just grab the dough with a generously floured hand and gentle form the scones. I bake on parchment, no need to grease. 

Baked mine 15-20 minutes as they are larger. These freeze extremely well and the air fryer resurrects them like they are fresh from the oven. 

Thank you for this amazing recipe. When my mom visits I make a double batch so we can enjoy them and she takes the rest home. Her favourite is toasted walnuts, and I like them with walnuts abs raisins.
Some of the best scones I have made. Deliciously light with a thin crisp outer layer .
It was helpful to create our very 1st scones.

So… ….good. I used pastry flour and butter with a higher fat content, and I didn’t let them sit ten minutes before putting in the oven. I also cut my butter up into small pieces, dust it with flour so the pieces don’t stick together and put in a bowl and put in the freezer for about an hour. Then right before mixing everything together, I take the butter out and break into pea sized pieces. Helps keep the butter solid until right before it goes in the oven.
It was the first time I made scones & they turned out delicious- light & fluffy! I read a lot of the reviews ahead of time & prepared the dough in a food processor & didn’t sift

What a simple and wonderful recipe! Great flavor and texture, and really easy to make! Instead of dried cranberries, I added chopped pecans, a few flaxseeds and about a teaspoon of cinnamon. YUM! :o)?

803rd rating. Believe the hype! Yes, these scones are that good. I read the reviews and took from the experiences of others ( which is why I love Allrecipes). I froze the butter, grated it, returned butter/flour to freezer. Made savory scones by omitting sugar. Used buttermilk and plain yogurt. Added cheddar cheese and green onions. Sprayed cooking spray on my bench scraper before cutting into triangles. They looked and smelled fantastic- and tasted great!!
I’m learning. I will make again. Next time easier. But they turned out fine

Very moist . They are not sweet but rather more like a biscuit . I added sanding sugar on the top to add same sweetness. I also used half and half instead of milk and added dried cherries. Could add white chocolate chips to add more sweetness if wanted.
Delicious recipe. Just as good as the ones I had on my trip to Ireland. Easy to make.
Excellent! Easy to make. I used fresh blueberries and they were delicious!
These are the best in the universe! And I’ve been to Scotland! Not dry, yet crumbly, just amazing....

The first time I made it exactly as per the recipe and it didn’t rise. I may have over mixed it even though I tried very hard not to. 
The second time I grated my 71g butter that was cold, into the mixture and then I put the whole mixture in the freezer for 10 minutes. I also did not use egg I used milk and I basically made a flat disc and put milk on the top and then separated it into eight portions. This time it rose beautifully
Wonderful!

I didn't have a few items on hand so I had to sub the sour cream for full-fat Greek yogurt and the milk for heavy cream and these scones STILL turned out fabulous. Easy to pull apart or cut in half, great texture and not too sweet.

OMG, incredible! I don't know what the people who wrote less than stellar reviews are talking about. If you follow a few advices in some of the comments, such as reducing baking powder by one teaspoon and grating frozen butter into the dry ingredients, the scones come out very tender, and light, and succulent. I didn't brush them with the egg wash, also an advice from a comment, and I did not miss it. Oh, I did add raisins, and -amazing! Cheese and rosemary next time!

First time doing this recipe. And they were a success to me & my fiancé who is a food snob (I love him but he usually doesn’t like the things I like). He says I need to make them every weekend. 

I followed recipe exactly because I am not a baker but it was fantastic. My kitchen smelled soooo good! And to whoever suggested using a cheese grater for the butter - THANK YOU. Again not a baker so I was looking at using my hands like recipe suggests. But the grater seems to have worked great! 10/10 will make again.
My wife loved this simple recipe

I made these for a get together where we made British themed food. My first time making scones, and they were delicious. I replaced the currants with dried cranberries but otherwise followed the recipe. They turned out great!
Best ever!
I made these. The best scones I had ever tasted.

Hands down the best scones recipe ever! I also followed tips from Care to reduce the baking powder to 3 tsp and place it in the fridge after rubbing in the butter. It turned out great! But i kinda let it bake a few minutes more and it browned a bit on top but still delicious! A little bit crunchy top and soft on the inside. Love it!
I have used this recipe so many times, and it never fails! Best tasting , and textured scones ever.

After all the amazing reviews, decided that I needed to give these a try. I'm a bit of a nerd, so I actually read through all the reviews and compiled the adjustments that others had suggested. I took the ones that came up most often and applied them to my efforts, and WOW....did I say WOW. These scones came out amazing. Not only did I think so, but so did the family, who requested another batch this weekend. I altered the flavor profile and once again had another hit.

So here's what I did with the ingredients... 1. Decreased the baking powder to 3 teaspoons. 2. Increased the butter to 6 tablespoons. 3. Added 1.5 tsp of vanilla 4. Eliminated the egg. 5. Substituted for the currants/raisins (more on that in a moment).

From a process perspective... 1. I threw the butter into the freezer the night before, and pulled it out when I needed it and chopped into pea size pieces. 2. After making the flour mix and adding the butter, I put the bowl in the freezer for 5 minutes. 3. Put the scones on parchment paper instead of greased cookie sheet. 4. Eliminated the egg wash and sprinkled generously with granulated sugar on top before baking. 5. Baked for 17 minutes when a toothpick came out clean. They still look quite blond at this time, but they are done.

Flavor alterations...
Batch 1 - peeled and chopped one granny smith apple to fill about 3/4 cup, and then coated with 1 tbl cornstarch and 1 tsp cinnamon. This was somebody else's idea and it was excellen
Best Scones I've ever made. And easy too!
This was my first attempt at making scones. They were delicious! I followed the recipe exactly as written.

easy, and ohh so good.
great recipe, great scone
Delicious scones! I’ve tried a few scone recipes but I just love the taste of this one. It’s what I imagine a scone should be.

These scones are phenomenal. At first I thought the dough was too dry and there was a lot of the flour butter mixture left out. I stuck with the don’t over work the dough mantra and just formed a disc with what stuck together. 
In the end, these turned out perfect. I totally forgot to add raisins but they taste great all by itself. Make these!! You will not regret it!

These were pretty good. I put in fresh blueberries instead of dried, but I diced them and baked them for a little while and squeezed out some of the moisture before adding them. The batter was still too wet so I had to add more flour to make up for the aded moisture. I also added lemon zest and a squeeze of lemon juice to the batter. After baking and cooling I topped it with a mix of powdered sugar, half and half, and lemon zest sauce.
Omg these are the lightest most delicious scones. The outside is crunchy and the inside is light and moist. Best recipe I have ever had even from a bakery!
Used Semi-sweet chocolate chips instead of cranberries. OMG! Tartness of chocolate with sweetness of scone was divine.
Delicious! I used frozen blueberries and it turned out really good. Everybody ate them up fast!

Amazing recipe!!! Light and fluffy! I made the following changes... I used self rising flour because of other reviews commenting on having to reduce the amount of baking soda due to bitterness. They rose up light and fluffy! I used blueberries for fruit but am making some chocolate chip and white chocolate raspberry in the morning so possibilities are endless! After brushing the tops with the egg/milk mixture I sprinkled them lightly with sugar. Finally, I recommend a longer baking time than the recipe calls for. It takes a good 20-25 minutes to get them a soft golden brown.

This has been by far the best scone recipe I have ever tried.. due to Covid lockdown... I had to substitute the sour cream with creme fraiche and I used salted butter and self raising flour.... thescones were fluffy and light ... the best ever !

Really delicious! I made it during quarantine so I had to improvise a little on ingredients. I didn’t have sour cream so I used plain yogurt and I substituted 1 T. of brown sugar for 1 T. of the white sugar and added some cinnamon because that sounded good. I used both raisins and dried cranberries. They came out perfect, best scones I ever ate, and I’m not an experienced baker.
Followed recipe precisely, no changes. Came out perfect!! This recipe is a keeper, reminded us of our years living in the UK!

I was very hopeful about this recipe but I thought it fell short of "the worlds best scone". I have spend some time in London and enjoyed a proper English scone and I felt this recipe did not hit the mark. For starters, 1/8 teas. of salt wasn't enough so it tasted bland. Additionally, I thought it lacked the creamy texture of a true English scone.

This recipe turned out just great! My family loved them. I followed the recipes to the T making sure I didn’t over mixed the dry ingredients with the wet ingredients like it says. The recipe made 12 scones, I made them in the morning for breakfast, by 6pm only one was left. This is a keeper!
Boring bland scone recipe. Would need a lot of modification to make it good. Even with chocolate chips and pecans it put us to sleep. I gave it a few stars because at least it wasn't a hockey puck.
easy, fast and yummy

Followed other reviewers' recommendations and reduced baking powder to 3 tsp and froze and grated butter into dough. Egg wash gave nice color. Mine were for 2 teenagers so added mini choc. chips rather than currants. Next time make for me with dried cranberry and add almond extract to mix. Make orange icing for top. May attempt clotted cream recipe in allrecipes also. I made mine into 12 smaller scones - 11 in pic because 1 in my tummy.

It’s light and cakey. It expands and doubles in size (or mine did at least). I added 1 tablespoon of lemon extract and 1.5 cups of frozen blueberries (which seems like a lot but almost every bite had a blueberry). I took the advice of others and grated the butter and mixed until just incorporated. I put the mixture in the freezer for 15 minutes just to make sure the butter wasn’t melted. The texture is cake like and not dense like the American scones. Two thumbs up, it would be perfect for a tea party or get together!

I made a couple of changes that added to the way I like scones. They are a lot more fluffier than baking soda biscuits and not as sharp.

 I left out the raisins/currants and I mixed the egg and milk then took half of it and added it to the recipe. I also used only 3 tsp of baking powder. 

They turned out a little lighter and not as crumbly. Add three min to overall baking time and don’t open the oven door at all.

I made these entirely by the book, no variations. Curious to see how blueberries will work in the next batch...

2nd batch has now been made, substitute plain yogurt for the sour cream, and blueberries. Very good. I think part of this batch got a little darker than the recipe suggests, but I like them
Exactly how I like them. Slightly sweet, perfect with a cup of tea. I plan on adapting the recipe further to my own tastes. Sometimes sweet, sometimes savory.

Great scones! I wanted a lemony flavour so replaced some of the milk with lemon juice and added the zest from one lemon. Didn't have currents, so used dried cranberries. Worked out well! The batter is definitely gooey and takes some work to stick together but it's worth it.
Best scones ever. Fluffy. Soft. Tasty! I made them got my annual Ladies Christmas Tea. I’ll be making them for my Valentines Tea!

This really is the best scone recipe I have ever used, and I've been baking scones for years.

Note: If you don't have sour cream, Greek yogurt works fine.
These scones are fantastic!!!! My new favorites

I messed these up so bad and they STILL came out great! I started making them and too late realized I didn't have any sour cream so I substituted SILK non-dairy yogurt - blueberry, mind you - and 1/2 c. of half-n-half for the milk. The batter was so dry and crumbly I had to add more h&h just to be able to handle it, but the outcome was divine and just about the most delicious scone I've ever had. Thanks for the recipe!

This is a great recipe! I've made it many times. You can turn them into cranberry orange scones by substituting dried cranberries for the raisins and adding orange zest (1/2 orange per recipe). They are the best!
I've made these a bunch of times, cooking them up in the morning to have with coffee. Last time I made them, I used dried tart cherries along with blueberries. So good!

I reduced the baking soda by 1 tsp and very happy I did that because I can still taste it. Now I made a huge gaff and forgot to throw in the salt so I’ll be trying this again. The texture is perfect though. They are light and fluffy. although mine came out flat even though I had let it rest I am hoping my next batch will taste better and I won’t forget the darn salt!
I made these for the first time for my Scottish family story. They turned out wonderfully and where a big hit. I also made the clotted cream to go with them

I didn't have milk so used cooking cream which i had at hand, instead. also used self-raising flour instead of all purpose flour + baking powder. It turned out absolutely amazing, buttery and indeed the best scones i have ever tasted!

only thing i will change next time is using half the sugar as husband felt it was too sweet for him. ;-)
The best
Oh my goodness! delicious, moist and fluffy. Used 3 tsp. of baking powder. Put dry mix in the freezer for 5 min. after butter was mixed in. Excellent!!!!
These are so good. Perfect consistency and easy to make. The whole family loved them. I just added cinnamon and vanilla for extra flavor.

Ooooohhhhh. I tried this recipe tonight with extra currants. I'm eating two hot out of the oven. So light and fluffy. I did not make them touch on the pan - they spread out a bit which probably helped the texture. Sooooo delicious. Will absolutely make these again but will try with other fruits and likely chocolate. Thank you - I've always enjoyed scones but a lot of the ones I buy are heavy on the fat. These are wonderful.

I made no changes in the recipe and they came out wonderful.
I will definity make them again.
this was easy and turned out some absolutely yummy scones. They weren't overly sweet and perfect with morning coffee. I'm excited to try some flavoring variants like bacon, cheese, herbs, etc.

These are really, really good! I only gave 3 stars because when I think of scones, I expect them to be a little sweeter. Another receipe I use has 1/3 c sugar and I think the little bit more sugar is perfect.
These are great slightly sweet biscuits. I put bacon and sharp cheddar cheese in mine for a more savory flavor.
Have made scones from many recipes, some of them quite good. This one, however, is far and away the best.
Made as written except I frozen, then grated in the butter. I did not let them rest 10 mins, just put them in the oven. Mine took 20 mins. to cook through. So good, slightly sweet, but not too sweet.

My first time baking scones ever and my what a treat! My family loves them and now baking these has become a must-do on Sunday evenings! Thank you for sharing . I also found the tips in the reviews to be very helpful. Changes I have made: used yoghurt instead of sour cream and omitted the sugar entirely. No egg wash either and I prefer tearing the dough over hand rolling into balls. (thank you for sharing this tip fellow scone baking enthusiasts! )I have made two types so far: sweet scones with fresh blueberries ( entirely without the sugar) and savoury chili cheese scones. The latter are more popular with my peeps. Just taking a fresh batch out of the oven. Next week, rosemary scones.
This will be my go-to recipe for scones. Reminded me of the scones I had at Guildford. Thought I'll never taste them again since I left UK. Thank you so much for sharing this recipe. Bless you.
A terrific hit at a bridal tea. The grated frozen butter trick is the bomb and the hand dipped biscuits look much more authentic!
These are the best scones I have ever made!

I love these scones. I have been making these for quite a few years. This year I decided to use tart cherries. I put the dried cherries in my steamer and put them in the refrigerator. When my dough was ready I added the cherries and my, oh my. Best cherry flavor ever! Steaming the Cherries works great. I did dried blueberries and didn’t steam them and the blueberry flavor is not there. So steam your dried fruit and you won’t be sorry!

They turned out perfectly and the flavor is perfectly matched my memory of the best scones I've eaten. Added dried cherries (my favorite). Parchment paper instead of a greased cookie sheet worked well. I used another recipe's idea and gently packed dough into a large ball and used a chef knife to divide into eight pieces. Then, gently again, formed into round "patties" three inches diameter by about 1.5 inches tall. 375 degree convection for 12 min worked best.

Very good recipe and easy to make with the kids. We added apples and cinnamon to the mix and they turned out great. It took a little longer to cook due to the increased moisture from the apples, so I think it was about 20 min cooking time and they turned out perfect. We will absolutely make this again.

Light and not too sweet. I mix My dry ingredients with cut up cold butter in my food processor until blended and then mix in my wet ingredients until just blended. I added dried cranberries and orange rind. I pat it down between two pieces of parchment paper and also bake it on parchment paper. I cut it in six triangles and bake for 15 minutes. I did not do the egg wash but made a glaze with orange juice and powdered sugar over the top of hot scones. Delicious
Fantastic! Fun and easy with the kids! Can't wait to make some more.

Just made the scone,oh my word they are the best scones I have ever made. I was scpeptical about the amount of baking powder but I did try it anyway cause I saw the reviews. I doubled the ingredients and added one egg??,voila . They are delicious ,crunchy outside and soft inside. ????. I’m glad I have tried the recipe.

I've never actually made a scone, but just returned from a trip to England and am craving scones. I thought what better activity to do during a Chicago polar vortex with 
-50 F windchill but bake! 

I made it exact except I didn't have any raisins or currants , so I left those out. In place of the milk I used half heavy cream and half milk. I also added the coarse sugar on top to bake since that's how they made them in England, and added a splash of vanilla.... just cause. I had to bake mine for 15 min. These were actually moist ! They were THE best scones I have ever had. I cannot wait to add different combos of fruits to them and also make a savory batch! Thank you for this recipe!
These were so delicious and very easy to make. I put everything in my food processor which made it even easier, and they turned out perfect!! So light and yummy!!

I wasn't sure about sour cream in my scones, but it sure is yummy. I added dried cherries to mine and they were out of this world good. I didn't do the egg wash thing either as I completely forgot. I bet the tops would be even better. 

Oh- and you know they don't have American sour cream in Scotland? Just learned that.

Yummy and easy. I cut out 1 tsp of baking powder. I made one batch with dried cranberries and grated orange peel, and another batch with chives and shredded sharp cheddar cheese (in this batch I only used 2 T of sugar). Both were delicious.

I reduced the baking soda by 1tsp. If I make them again I will reduce by 2tsp. They leave the after taste of baking soda. They are very soft inside. Nice texture. I added 1tsp of vanilla and lemon zest. Also used craisins instead of raisins. I did not think they were sweet as some other reviewers suggested. I did drizzle with a light drizzle of powder sugar, vanilla and milk mixture.
Excellent as written! Thank you for a great recipe!
I put cranberries in it! Turned out great!!!
I made these for a Thanksgiving party. To keep on theme, I used craisins instead of raisins, and they were a hit at the party!
Scrumptious! Rave reviews from everyone!

I used self-rising flour (because of the baking powder issues). Grated my butter. I did add 1 tbsp. of cinnamon (wasn't enough) and used raisins. Sprinkled the tops with raw sugar. Egg wash gave them a nice brown and they rose nicely. With my morning coffee, they were a nice treat.
I didn’t have milk but I used half and half and tried to mix them softly . Scooped them out of the bowl as one of the reviewers had described. They came out great and moist not dry.

I made the World's Best Scones this morning and my husband and I are now converts! They were light, tender and so delicious we chose to eat them with just a little butter. No need for the preserves. The recipe, exactly as written, is perfect. Unlike some other reviewers, I did not find the baking powder to be too much and experienced no after taste. The color from the egg and milk wash is beautiful and so inviting. I am looking forward to variations, but the recipe as written cannot be improved upon. Truly the world's best scone! Thank you, FRIENDLYFOOD!
Follow the recipe, but use Craisins instead of currants. Turned out great. Will make double batch next time. Thanks for sharing.

I made a batch this morning. I cut the cold butter into small cubes and used a pastry cutter to work with the dry ingredients. I used whole milk and full fat sour cream. The dough was very sticky, so make sure you have flour available on the side. I gently pressed the dough into a circle and cut out eight wedges. I did not use the egg as it seemed like a waste (unless you are making scrambled eggs). I brushed the scones with buttermilk, or you can use heavy cream. I sprinkled vanilla sugar on the top of each scone. It took about 17 minutes in my oven. They were good, and I would describe the texture as crunchy biscuits that are tender, soft and fluffy inside.

I am on a scone-quest, and these are a delicious option. I only wish that the recipe and the video correlated ; the recipe says to bake them 'cozy' together and the video sets them apart. I followed the recipe and got one huge scone! They were separable, but not as pretty.I used self-rising flour and added one tsp of baking soda and just a pinch of salt. Next time, I'll skip the baking soda altogether or just use regular flour and cut the soda in half. Kind of sweet, but nice texture with the sour cream added.

These are quite good, and easy to make. My whole family enjoyed them. I like that I could save a step by just rolling them into a balls, and then press flat, rather than patty down the entire dough, then cutting round with a biscuit cutter, or into wedge some with a knife. I substituted blueberries for the currants, and drizzled with a lemon glaze (1 c powdered sugar, 1/4 c lemon juice, zest of 1/2 lemon, and 1/2 TBS of butter, all heated over double boiler, whisking til smooth). Served with hot Earl Grey tea. Being true scones, they do have a biscuit-like texture, so if you prefer the very sweet dense kind of scones you can buy at grocery store here in the U.S. , this recipe may not be for you.

First time making these with slight modifications and they were so delicious. Instead of milk I used heavy whipping cream. I added zest from one orange and use Craisins. I sprinkled raw sugar on top for added effect. Cooking time was 17 minutes. I don’t have a sifter so as I poured dry ingredients into a fine strainer, my husband helped shake it to simulate sifting. LOL it worked.

Love this recipe! They turned out perfectly. I left out the raisins and added cinnamon (because I LOVE cinnamon.) This was my brothers' first time having a scone. One said it tasted just like a normal biscuit, while my eldest brother thought it tasted like oats! They liked them, even though they weren't sure what they were : )Definitely making these again.

Wonderful. So moist, like eating cake. I didn't have any sour cream, just used whole milk. I mixed in dried cranberries. I was very careful about mixing, and spooned the dough onto the cookie sheet, lightly touching each one. I will definitely make these again when I get some sour cream. Although I can't imagine them being any more delicious! Thanks for the great recipe !
it came out soft and fluffy although i had to bake it for 25 mins as 15 mins it was still doughy.. but its still a wonderful recipe!

item.name: World's Best Scones! From Scotland to the Savoy to the U.S.
